page.title: List of Nobel laureates affiliated with Imperial College London

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} [[File:ImperialCollegeLondon.jpg|thumb|200px|Fifteen Nobel laureates have been affiliated with [[Imperial College London]]. The building pictured is the [[Royal School of Mines]].]] The [[Nobel Prize]]s are awarded annually by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], the [[Karolinska Institute]], and the [[Norwegian Nobel Committee]] to individuals who make outstanding contributions in the fields of [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|chemistry]], [[Nobel Prize in Physics|physics]], [[Nobel Prize in Literature|literature]], [[Nobel Peace Prize|peace]], and [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|physiology or medicine]].{{cite web | title = Alfred Nobel – The Man Behind the Nobel Prize | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/alfred_nobel/|accessdate=2009-03-14}} They were established by the 1895 will of [[Alfred Nobel]], which dictates that the awards should be administered by the [[Nobel Foundation]]. Another prize, the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]], was established in 1968 by the [[Sveriges Riksbank]], the [[central bank]] of [[Sweden]], for contributors to the field of economics.{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/|title=The Nobel Prize|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2009-03-14}} Each prize is awarded by a separate committee: the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awards the Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, and Economics, the Karolinska Institute awards the Prize in Physiology or Medicine, and the Norwegian Nobel Committee awards the Prize in Peace.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Awarders |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015013145/http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |archivedate=2008-10-15 }} Each recipient receives a medal, a diploma and a cash prize that has varied throughout the years. In 1901, the winners of the first Nobel Prizes were given 150,782 [[Swedish krona|SEK]], which is equal to 7,731,004 SEK in December 2007. In 2008, the winners were awarded a prize amount of 10,000,000 SEK.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Amounts |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205035938/http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |archivedate=February 5, 2009 }} The awards are presented in [[Stockholm]] in an annual ceremony on December 10, the [[anniversary]] of Nobel's death.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Award Ceremonies |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228154556/http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |archivedate=February 28, 2009 }} As of 2009, there have been 15 Nobel laureates affiliated with [[Imperial College London]]. Imperial College considers laureates who attended the university as undergraduate students, graduate students or were members of the faculty as affiliated laureates.{{cite web|url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/aboutimperial/imperial_people/nobel_laureates|title=Nobel Laureates|publisher=[[Imperial College London]]|accessdate=2009-03-14}} [[Frederick Gowland Hopkins]], who attended the [[Royal School of Mines]] from 1881 to 1883, was the first Imperial College-affiliated laureate, winning the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1929.{{cite web| url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1929/index.html| title = The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1929| accessdate = 2009-03-14| publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}} One Nobel Prize was shared by two Imperial College laureates; [[Ernst Boris Chain]] and [[Alexander Fleming]] won the 1945 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.{{cite web| url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1945/index.html| title = The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1945| accessdate = 2009-03-14| publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}} Thirteen of the fifteen Imperial College laureates were members of the faculty. Nine laureates were [[Research fellow|fellow]]s of the college. No Imperial College laureate has won the Nobel Prize in Literature, the Nobel Peace Prize, or the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Laureates== {|class="wikitable sortable" width="98%" style="background:#ffffff;" |- !
